speaker: Wilson Smith
transcript: Yeah. So so we we talked about this in in the last subgroup is that you know at NREL we've done technoeconomic and life cycle assessments of different pathways for you know full air to barrel scenarios. And as you scale up CO2 electrolysis, whether you use something like Opus 12, which is a PEM electrolysis in acid or something like dioxide, which is alkaline, as you scale this up to you know more than 10 to 50,000 units of production, the major cost in both of those systems is the membranes. So the idea of the catalyst cost is not it's it's nothing. Even the bipolar plates are a small thing. Separations aren't too bad if we can do this well, but for both of them, the real limiting step is the cost of membranes and both the the base materials but then also the manufacturing at large scale. So I think that's where we can kind of you know look at which you know how did batteries get 10x cheaper in 10 years? Was it the cathodes that got cheaper? Was it a better electrolyte? I think we can learn like people have said from these other fields, how did they improve efficiency, reduce cost? Usually to material component or stability or durability. And and for electrolyzers, we I mean all the modeling points in any case whether we do this in acidic or alkaline conditions, the membranes are going to be the driver for for the cost.
screenshare_content: The shared screen content remains the same static text document.

speaker: Jordi Cabana
transcript: I will note though that in all and this is not to badmouth, it's going to come out much worse than I mean it, but in all these models, there's the assumption that technology and performance stays constant in a sense, right? speaker: Wilson Smith
transcript: So the first question for the kind of discussion was a life cycle assessment. Now for technoeconomic assessment, we actually do a sensitivity analysis to see which operational or material parameters would lead to the biggest shift in cost. And there we see that the biggest drivers are the single pass conversion efficiency and the current density. Now the issue with that is that if you look in literature, those are things where it's kind of like whack-a-mole. If somebody can do very good current current density, they have very low single pass conversion. If they have very good single pass conversion, they have low current. So in the end, we ideally would like them both. And then that is to us a frontier is that how can you do both of those things at the same time? And that takes I don't think that that's going to be solved by a cascade reaction. I think that's going to be reactor engineering and process integration that's going to solve that, not not a cascade on a catalyst surface.
screenshare_content: The shared screen content remains the same static text document.
other: The speaker uses a hand gesture to illustrate the "whack-a-mole" concept he is describing.

annotations.ask question: Wilson Smith is seeking insights into how to achieve both high single pass conversion efficiency and current density at the same time, posing a clear question about solving this challenge.

speaker: Wilson Smith
transcript: So there is a single pass limit and Feng Jiao has done some work on this as well. The the limit under any conditions is about 60% because then at some conversion of of flow rates and current density, the CO2 is consumed by the electrolyte and the hydroxides. So 60% is the best you can get. Matt Kanan had a nice paper on this recently. But the way to get around that is just to do CO electrolysis because CO2 to CO is industrial. You can buy from Haldor Topsoe a skid that's you know the size of your basement and do CO2 to CO very well, very efficient, very selective, energy efficient. I mean again, you can buy it from Haldor Topsoe on their website. You can buy one off the shelf, pretty big, like a shipping container. It's pretty cool.

speaker: Jordi Cabana
transcript: Single pass conversion okay. So you know when you look inside the reactor what is you know what is driving that that competition is that something that is as simple as reactor design or is it just that your catalyst cannot transform fast enough?
screenshare_content: A document remains shared in a small window at the top of the screen. The content is static text. No changes are made during this segment.

speaker: Wilson Smith
transcript: It's reactor design and the electrolyte. So if you're doing CO2 even if you start with a basic electrolyte if you start to run it more than 10 or 20 milliamps it's going to become alkaline spontaneously. So it's the electrolyte consumption but then with the with the kind of transport control there are things like pressure drops that will change and it depends on if you're making CO2 to CO so a gas feedstock to a gas product the the pressure drop across your electrode will be small but if you want to make a liquid product you will create a much bigger pressure drop across your electrode and the effects down the channel will be much more significant. So it's there there's a lot of competing factors which is why I think you know CO2 electrolysis won't scale the same way that water electrolysis does. You know selectivity is not an issue for water electrolysis. Partial pressure differences across the electrodes is is managed very well and I think for for CO2 reduction it's so big you can make a gas you can make a liquid you can make lots of products they're much more sensitive to to changing their performance based on scaling relations.
screenshare_content: A document remains shared in a small window at the top of the screen. The content is static text. No changes are made during this segment.

annotations.offer feedback: Wilson's explanation provides specific insights into the challenges of CO2 electrolysis, which can be seen as feedback on how to approach or understand the process.
